awd_titl_txt: ICBR:  Repurposing Infrastructure to Advance State of the Art Research Methods, Keys Marine Lab
awd_abstract_narration:
The Keys Marine Lab (KML) is a full-service laboratory supporting the mission of Florida's State University System (SUS) as part of the Florida Institute of Oceanography (FIO). The mission of the SUS to achieve "excellence in teaching, research and public service" is reflected in the mission of KML which is to educate the marine scientists of tomorrow by providing on site and field research experiences and state of the art tools for teaching and for research. KML's location in the middle of the only living barrier reef in the continental US with subtropical and tropical ecosystems, attracts scientists, faculty, undergraduate and graduate students, from around the world. KML was designated, with FIO, as an Academic Infrastructure Support Organization (AISO) by the SUS Board of Governors in 2015. As such, the laboratory is mandated to provide the infrastructure, tools and expertise, needed to support academic programs and research, with an emphasis on field and comparative laboratory experiences. A well-based seawater system was constructed at KML in 2015 to provide experimental research capability for hind-cast and forecast predictions of water quality. This facility supports research on two coral species listed under the Endangered Species Act, staghorn and pillar coral. Demand for the use of this system has grown dramatically and the funds provided under this award will expand the capacity and improve the functionality of this critical system.

The flow through system will be upgraded to provide the ability to manipulate water quality, including temperature, pH, pO2 and simultaneously provide real time bay to up to 62 tanks that range in size from 1 to 1100 gallons. Specific improvements are: 1) provide sea water at current salinity, temperature and oxygen saturation, that can be changed while simultaneously being able to provide water that is representative of current conditions to an additional 62 tanks already available via the Bay water system; 2) provide the ability to conduct mesocosm research with water representing past, present or future water quality conditions in an environment of varying depth equivalent to average coastal Florida Bay depth in the middle Keys; 3) to provide the new ability to conduct research using real time water quality with water of different quality from small scale, 1 gallon tanks to the mesocosm scale at approximate average depth of Florida Bay in the nearshore Middle Keys. These improvements will provide a mesocosm that can be used to simulate the near coastal waters of Florida Bay in the middle Keys where the laboratory is located. For more information about KML and this seawater system, visit their website at http://www.keysmarinelab.org/.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The Florida Institute of Oceanography (FIO) is an Academic Infrastructure Support Organization of Florida's State University System and hosted at the University of South Florida. One of the most important infrastructure assets of FIO is the Keys Marine Laboratory (KML), a full-service marine field station located on Long Key (Layton, FL) in the Florida Keys. KML enables college-level education and research across all institutions and stakeholders at the local, state, national, and international levels. The principle function of KML is to serve the academic and research community through 1) field trips supporting undergraduate and graduate programs across the state and region, 2) research support for a number of projects requiring access to the complex coral reef/seagrass/mangrove ecosystems surrounding KML, and 3) the state-of-the-art seawater systems for the culture and experimentation on corals and other organisms needed for the long term survival and recovery of these critically threatened ecosystems.

While the existing seawater systems at Keys Marine Laboratory currently provide the ability to mimic past, present, and future water quality, at varying temporal scales, this ability is limited to only forty (40) experimental tanks and tables.

The major goals for this project are:

  1. The addition of a second seawater well degassing tower to increase the output of high-quality seawater supply for research projects at Keys Marine Laboratory
  2. Repair, deepen, and resurface an existing shallow seawater pool in response to increasing requests to conduct laboratory-based research in a mesocosm as a proxy for the near-shore environment of Florida Bay and the Middle Keys.
  3. Provide increased seawater capacity for additional temperature-controlled experimental tanks under a new greenhouse shade structure and to augment water flow to the large seawater pool (The Shallows)

The Florida Keys include the only living barrier coral reef system in the continental US and as such is inherently valuable to the greater US and the world. The habitats of the Florida Keys have an asset value of $8.5 billion and  bring $4.4 billion to the economy, which includes eco-tourism and fishing, both commercial and recreational.  Sustainability of these habitats is critical to the economy of the Keys, the State of Florida, and the greater region. KML?s strategic location in the middle of the Florida Keys offers access to subtropical and tropical ecosystems, attracting scientists, undergraduate, and graduate students, from around the world.  Improvements and upgrades fresulting from this NSF-funded project will have far-reaching effects on the scientific community for decades to come.

Infrastructure upgrades and improvements will immediately double the present seawater system capacity at KML and provide the ability to accommodate the increasing demand for use of the existing system at variability of spatial and temporal scales, with the ability to represent water quality any time of the year regardless of real time conditions. The expanded capacity to conduct field and laboratory experiments on site will minimize the need to transport organisms to home laboratories, thereby reducing the risk  of mortality and negatively impacting research results. Comparative studies of past, present, and forecast changes in climate can be completed on site and compared with real time water quality conditions in both Florida Bay and the Atlantic Ocean

The upgrades to the Bay Seawater System will provide for the ability to enhance water quality in the large Shallows mesocosm, within a range limited by ambient conditions. Upgrading and deepening the mesocosm will provide the new ability to conduct research on the development of sampling and observational tools and equipment in a controlled laboratory setting.

Academic programs that include hands-on or experiential learning have been shown to accelerate learning, increase student engagement, and deliver exceptional return on investment. KML focuses its academic efforts on providing hands on-learning experiences offered in a safe and controlled environment to both undergraduate and graduate students. Expandition of the seawater system capabilities will provide new opportunities both on-site at the marine field station and in the adjacent near shore waters minimizing the need to range far beyond the boundaries of the laboratory and its coastal waters and habitat. KML is ideally situated to provide comparative real time field studies while conducting laboratory research under varying environmental conditions.

Addionally, FIO's Keys Marine Laboratory is centrally located along the Florida Reef Tract to assist as a pass-through and holding facility for current and future reef restoration activities, providing temperature-controlled reef quality water for critical coral reef restoration efforts. These NSF infrastructure upgrades and improvements at KML will greatly enhance capacity for marine research and education as we enter the Ocean Decade while developing marine scientists for the future of our oceans.


Last Modified: 12/03/2024
Modified by: Cynthia Lewis
